openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Cuba is characterized as a planned economy predominantly operated through state-run enterprises.
• The Communist Party of Cuba maintains extensive control over the economy, exerting significant influence over economic policies and activities.
• Cuba benefits from a low cost of living, inexpensive public transportation, and subsidized services including education, healthcare, and food.
• The country's economic growth has historically been weak, hindered by high levels of labor emigration, dependence on imports, an ongoing energy crisis, foreign trade sanctions, and limited tourism.
• Cuba's dual economy has contributed to a series of financial crises, reflecting structural economic challenges.
• Since 2020, Cuba has been experiencing an economic recession characterized by high inflation, widespread poverty, and food shortages.
• In the 19th century, Cuba was one of the most prosperous pre-industrial Latin American countries, exporting tobacco, sugar, and coffee.
• During the Cuban Revolution (1953–1959), under the military dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista, Cuba's GDP per capita ranked seventh in Latin America.

• Throughout the Cold War, Cuba's economy was heavily subsidized by the Eastern Bloc, with subsidies constituting between 10% and 40% of Cuba's GDP in various years, due to its geopolitical alignment with the Soviet Union.
• The collapse of the Soviet Union led to a severe economic downturn in Cuba, with GDP declining by 33% between 1990 and 1993.

• The period from 1991 to 2001, known as the Special Period, was marked by prolonged economic malaise, which was alleviated through marginal liberalization measures and foreign support, particularly from Venezuela.
• The United States has maintained an economic embargo against Cuba since 1958, driven by ongoing geopolitical tensions.
• The public sector accounts for the majority of economic activity in Cuba, with the government promoting the development of worker cooperatives and self-employment starting in the 1990s.
• In 2018, Cuba legalized limited private property rights and free-market activities, as well as foreign direct investment, marking a shift towards economic liberalization.
• Despite high employment levels in the public sector, private sector employment has been steadily decreasing since the 1980s.
• All significant private and public investment activities require government approval or oversight, limiting market autonomy.
• Economic data published by the Cuban government is not always independently verified, which hampers Cuba's inclusion in Latin American economic rankings.
• Since the 1870s, Cuba was classified among the high-income countries of Latin America, yet it experienced significant income inequality and capital outflows to foreign investors.
• The Cuban economy experienced rapid growth in the early 20th century, primarily driven by the export of sugar to the United States.
• In 1958, just before the Cuban Revolution, Cuba's per-capita GDP was $2,363, positioning it in the middle range among Latin American countries.
• According to the United Nations, between 1950 and 1955, Cuba had a life expectancy of 59.4 years, ranking 56th globally in this metric.
• Cuba’s geographical proximity to the United States made it a popular holiday destination for wealthy Americans, with tourism centered around gambling, horse racing, and golfing activities.
• The tourism magazine _Cabaret Quarterly_ described Havana as "a mistress of pleasure, the lush and opulent goddess of delights," highlighting its reputation for leisure and entertainment.
• Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista planned to develop Havana’s Malecon, a famous waterfront walkway, by lining it with hotels and casinos to further attract tourists.
• In the late 1950s, Cuba’s oil industry was dominated by three major international oil companies: Standard Oil of New Jersey (Esso), Texaco, and Royal Dutch Shell.

• On 3 March 1959, Fidel Castro seized control of the Cuban Telephone Company, a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telecommunications Corporation, marking the beginning of widespread nationalizations; the assets seized totaled US$9 billion.

• Following the 1959 Revolution, the Cuban government abolished personal income tax, with salaries considered net of taxes, and initiated subsidies for healthcare and education for all citizens, which garnered strong national support for the revolutionary government.
• Cuba and the USSR reestablished diplomatic relations in May 1960, strengthening their political and economic ties.
• When major oil refineries such as Shell, Texaco, and Esso refused to refine Soviet oil, Castro nationalized these industries on the island, taking control of the refineries.

• In response to Cuba’s nationalizations, the United States completely cut the Cuban sugar quota days later; President Dwight D. Eisenhower characterized this action as "economic sanctions against Cuba" and indicated the need to consider other economic, diplomatic, and strategic measures.
• In 1960, Cuba and the Soviet Union signed their first trade agreement, whereby Cuba exported sugar to the USSR in exchange for fuel, establishing a vital economic partnership.

• Soviet subsidies financed Cuba’s large state budget but did not lead to the development of a self-sustaining economy; despite this, Cuba was described as "a relatively highly developed Latin American export economy" in 1959 and early 1960s.

• Cuba’s primary exports remained cigars and cigarettes, produced mainly through pre-industrial piecework, with the economy characterized by inefficiency and over-specialization in a few commodities primarily sold to Eastern Bloc countries.
• The Cuban economy remained largely unchanged from the Revolution until 1990, maintaining a structure heavily reliant on Soviet aid and exports.
• On 7 February 1962, President John F. Kennedy expanded the U.S. embargo to include nearly all U.S. imports from Cuba, intensifying economic isolation.

• By the late 1960s, Cuba had become dependent on Soviet economic, political, and military aid, with Castro privately believing that Cuba could bypass the traditional stages of socialism and move directly to pure communism.

• In 1973, under pressure from Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev, Castro agreed to Cuba’s full membership in the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (Comecon), which classified Cuba as an underdeveloped member country.
• As a Comecon member, Cuba obtained oil in exchange for sugar at highly favorable rates, facilitating the import of goods from non-Comecon countries and supporting investments in social services.
• The favorable exchange rates and re-exporting of oil provided Cuba with hard currency, which was used to import goods from outside the Eastern Bloc and to finance social development initiatives.

• In 1970, as part of the Revolutionary Offensive economic campaign, Fidel Castro launched an initiative called _La Zafra_ with the goal of harvesting 10 million tons of sugar to boost exports and grow the Cuban economy.
• Despite widespread participation from the Cuban population, the country fell short of this target, producing only 7.56 million tons of sugar in 1970.

• After the harvest concluded in July 1970, Fidel Castro publicly took responsibility for the failure; however, later in the same year, he shifted blame to the Sugar Industry Minister, criticizing technocrats and scientists for overestimating their capabilities and for resource misallocation.

• Castro accused the technocrats of claiming they knew how to produce 10 million tons, but failing to do so, and of exploiting the rest of the economy by receiving large resource allocations, which could have been better distributed to improve factory productivity.

• During the revolutionary period, Cuba distinguished itself as one of the few developing countries to provide foreign aid to other nations, beginning with the construction of six hospitals in Peru in the early 1970s.

• Between 1970 and 1985, Cuba experienced high growth rates, notably in satisfying basic needs such as education and health, following a development model aligned with the World Bank’s 1970s strategy of redistribution combined with growth.
• Cuban foreign aid expanded significantly during the 1970s, with approximately 8,000 Cubans working in overseas assignments across various countries.
• Cuban aid efforts included building housing, roads, airports, schools, and other infrastructure in Angola, Ethiopia, Laos, Guinea, Tanzania, and additional countries.
• By the end of 1985, around 35,000 Cuban workers had contributed to development projects in approximately 20 countries across Asia, Africa, and Latin America.

• In 1982, Cuba pledged over $130 million worth of agricultural and machinery equipment to Nicaragua, along with dispatching about 4,000 technicians, doctors, and teachers to support the Sandinista revolution.
• Throughout the 1980s, Cuba supplied Nicaragua with approximately 90,000 tons of oil annually to support its revolutionary government.
• In 1986, Cuba defaulted on its $10.9 billion debt owed to the Paris Club, and in 1987, it ceased making payments on this debt.
• In 2002, Cuba defaulted on $750 million in loans from Japan, marking continued challenges in its international debt obligations.
• The Cuban gross domestic product (GDP) declined by at least 35% between 1989 and 1993, marking a severe economic contraction during this period.
• The economic decline was primarily due to the loss of approximately 80% of Cuba’s trading partners, significantly reducing trade volume and economic activity.
• The collapse of Soviet subsidies, which had previously supported Cuba’s economy, coincided with this period of decline, exacerbating economic hardships.

• The loss of subsidies from the Soviet Union occurred alongside a collapse in world sugar prices, which had been favorable from 1985 to 1990 but crashed precipitously in 1990 and 1991, remaining depressed for five years.
• Prior to the collapse, Cuba had been insulated from fluctuations in world sugar prices through Soviet price guarantees, which shielded its economy from market volatility.
• Following the deterioration of economic conditions, Cuba’s economy began to show signs of improvement after 1998, driven by a rapid improvement in trade and diplomatic relations with Venezuela.
• The improvement was largely due to Venezuela, especially after the election of Hugo Chávez in 1998, who became Cuba’s most important trading partner and diplomatic ally.
• The era of economic crisis during this period is referred to as the "Special Period in Peacetime," later shortened to "Special Period."

• A study published in the _Canadian Medical Association Journal_ attributed the famine in Cuba during the Special Period to political and economic factors similar to those in North Korea in the mid-1990s, where authoritarian regimes denied ordinary people access to sufficient food.
• The collapse of public food distribution systems and the prioritization of food for the elite classes and military contributed to widespread food shortages and famine conditions.
• Reports from the period describe extreme measures taken by Cubans to survive, including eating anything available such as animals from Havana Zoo and domestic cats.

• Despite severe economic difficulties, the collapse of centrally planned economies in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe led to a significant drop in average daily caloric intake in Cuba, from 3052 calories in 1989 to 2600 calories in 2006.
• Mortality rates in Cuba were not strongly affected during this period, largely due to the government’s efforts to maintain a social safety net and prioritize public health.

• The Cuban government implemented several reforms between 1994 and 2011 aimed at addressing excess liquidity, enhancing labor incentives, and mitigating shortages of food, consumer goods, and services.

• To combat the economic crisis, reforms included opening the economy to tourism, permitting foreign investment, legalizing the U.S. dollar, and authorizing self-employment in approximately 150 occupations.
• The policy of U.S. dollar legalization was later partially reversed; while the dollar is no longer accepted in businesses, it remains legal for Cubans to hold the currency.
• These reforms led to modest economic growth during this period.

• In October 1994, liberalized agricultural markets were introduced, allowing state and private farmers to sell above-quota production at free market prices, expanding legal consumption options, and reducing black market prices.

• The Cuban government sought to reduce subsidies to unprofitable enterprises and contracted the money supply, causing the semi-official exchange rate for the Cuban peso to decline from a peak of 120 to the dollar in summer 1994 to 21 to the dollar by the end of 1999.

• Cuba’s GDP growth was 0.7% in 1994, followed by 2.5% in 1995 and 7.8% in 1996; growth slowed to 2.5% in 1997 and 1.2% in 1998, primarily due to the failure to recognize the unprofitability of sugar production.

• Fidel Castro later admitted that mistakes were made during the Special Period, questioning why the industry’s decline was not recognized earlier given the collapse of the Soviet Union, oil prices at $40 per barrel, and low sugar prices.
• Living conditions in 1999 remained significantly below the levels of 1989.
• The historical evolution of Cuba’s GDP per capita, based on Maddison and Cuban statistics, shows a decline relative to other Caribbean countries over time.
• Tourism growth contributed to economic recovery, with GDP increasing by 6.2% in 1999 and further accelerating to 11.8% in 2005 according to government data.
• In 2007, Cuba’s economy grew by 7.5%, surpassing the Latin American average, with cumulative GDP growth since 2004 reaching 42.5%.
• Starting in 1996, the Cuban government imposed income taxes on self-employed individuals.
• In 1958, Cuba ranked third in the Caribbean region in GDP per capita, behind Venezuela and Uruguay; by 2007, it had fallen to 9th, 11th, or 12th place in the region.
• Despite economic challenges, Cuban social indicators experienced less deterioration compared to economic metrics.

• The United Nations annually votes on whether the U.S. economic embargo against Cuba is justified and should be lifted; in 2016, the U.S. abstained from voting for the first time since 1992, having previously voted against the resolution along with Israel.
• In its 2020 report, Cuba stated that the total economic cost of the U.S. embargo since its inception is approximately $144 billion.
• In December 2010, President Raúl Castro stated, "Either we change course or we sink," highlighting the urgent need for economic reforms in Cuba.
• In 2011, Cuba introduced significant economic reforms creating a new economic system, referred to by the Brookings Institution as the "New Cuban Economy."
• Since the reform implementation, over 400,000 Cubans have registered as entrepreneurs, indicating a substantial shift toward private enterprise.
• As of 2012, the Cuban government officially listed 181 jobs no longer under state control, including roles such as taxi driver, construction worker, and shopkeeper.
• Workers in certain sectors are required to purchase licenses to work in roles like mule driver, palm-tree trimmer, or well digger, reflecting increased privatization.

• Despite these reforms, Cuba maintains nationalized companies responsible for distributing essential amenities such as water and power, and providing healthcare and education to ensure public health.
• Around 2000, approximately half of Cuba’s sugar mills closed, indicating a decline in the sugar industry.
• Prior to reforms, Cuba’s imports were double its exports; doctors earned approximately £15 per month, and families supplemented incomes through additional jobs.
• Post-reforms, over 150,000 farmers gained the ability to lease land from the government for surplus crop production, promoting agricultural privatization.
• Real estate transactions, previously limited to property swaps, were legalized, leading to a real estate boom in Cuba.
• In 2012, La Pachanga, a Havana-based fast-food restaurant started in the owner’s home, served 1,000 meals on a Saturday at £3 each, exemplifying small private enterprise growth.
• Tourists can now ride factory steam locomotives through closed sugar mills, indicating increased tourism and private sector engagement with historical sites.
• In 2008, Raúl Castro’s administration hinted at legalizing the purchase of computers, DVD players, and microwaves; however, monthly wages remained below 20 U.S. dollars.
• Mobile phones, previously restricted to foreign workers and government officials, were legalized in 2008, expanding telecommunications access.
• In 2010, Fidel Castro acknowledged that the Soviet-style centralized planning model was unsustainable, aligning with Raúl Castro’s reformist stance.
• The Castro brothers promoted a cooperative form of socialism, emphasizing reduced state intervention and the development of worker-owned cooperatives and self-employment enterprises.
• On 18 April 2011, Cuba’s Sixth Congress approved extensive reforms to address economic distortions, including:
• expenditure adjustments in education, healthcare, sports, and culture;
• restructuring employment to reduce inflated payrolls and boost non-state sector employment;
• legalization of 201 different personal business licenses;
• leasing of fallow state land to residents under usufruct rights;
• incentives to promote non-state employment and re-launch self-employment;
• proposals for forming non-agricultural cooperatives;
• legalization of private sale and ownership of homes and cars;
• granting greater autonomy to state firms;
• strategies aimed at food self-sufficiency, reducing universal rationing, and targeting aid to the poorest;
• allowing rent of state-run enterprises, including restaurants, to self-employed individuals;
• separation of state and business functions;
• updates to tax policies;
• easing travel restrictions for Cubans;
• strategies for external debt restructuring.

• On 20 December 2011, a new credit policy was implemented, allowing Cuban banks to finance entrepreneurs, individuals for major purchases, home improvements, and farmers, building on existing credit provisions to farm cooperatives and farmland recipients since 2008.

• The rationing system, known as _Libreta de Abastecimiento_, continued as of 2012, with ration books at bodegas providing rice, oil, sugar, and matches, often above the government’s average wage of £15 monthly.
• As of 2012, Cuba’s public debt was 35.3% of GDP, inflation stood at 5.5%, and GDP growth was 3%, though these figures require updates.
• In September 2013, Raúl Castro signed Law 313 to establish the Mariel Special Economic Zone, Cuba’s first zone exempt from standard economic legislation, located in the port city of Mariel.
• On 22 October 2013, Cuba announced plans to end the dual-currency system; the convertible peso (CUC) ceased issuance from 1 January 2021 and circulation ended on 30 December 2021.
• The socialist social policy, which facilitated social advancement for underprivileged classes, was challenged by economic crises and low wages, leading to increased socio-economic disparities.

• The Cuban National Bureau of Statistics (ONE) reports that social inequalities are increasingly visible, with Afro-Cubans being particularly disadvantaged; 58% of white Cubans earn less than $3,000 annually, compared to 95% of Afro-Cubans, who also receive limited remittances from the Cuban-American community in South Florida.
• Remittances are crucial for private sector development, especially in lucrative sectors like restaurants and lodging, which are predominantly run by white Cubans.
• In February 2019, Cubans approved a new constitution granting rights to private property and greater access to free markets, while maintaining Cuba’s socialist identity.
• The 16th ExpoCaribe trade fair took place in Santiago in June 2019, reflecting increased trade activity.

• Since 2014, Cuba experienced a significant rise in foreign investment; by November 2019, 525 foreign direct investment projects were reported, up from 246 in 2014, despite deteriorating US-Cuba relations.
• In February 2021, the Cuban Cabinet authorized private initiatives in over 1,800 occupations, expanding private sector opportunities.

• The Cuban economy was severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and additional US sanctions imposed by the Trump administration; in 2020, the economy contracted by 11%, its worst decline in nearly 30 years, causing shortages of basic goods.

• Raúl Castro's government initiated a comprehensive effort to restructure Cuba's international debt and seek forgiveness for loans and debts owed by creditor countries, many amounting to billions of dollars and long overdue from loans incurred under Fidel Castro during the 1970s and 1980s.
• In 2011, China forgave $6 billion of debt owed by Cuba, significantly reducing Cuba's debt burden with China.

• In 2013, Mexico's Finance Minister Luis Videgaray announced that a loan issued by Mexico's foreign trade development bank, Bancomext, more than 15 years prior, was valued at $487 million; Mexico agreed to waive approximately 70% of this amount, equivalent to about $340.9 million, with Cuba scheduled to repay the remaining $146.1 million over ten years.

• In 2014, Russian President Vladimir Putin forgave over 90% of Cuba's debt to Russia, totaling $32 billion, with the remaining $3.2 billion to be paid over ten years; this forgiveness occurred prior to Putin's diplomatic visit to Cuba.

• In 2015, Cuba entered negotiations concerning its $11.1 billion debt to 14 members of the Paris Club; by December 2015, an agreement was reached whereby the Paris Club nations agreed to forgive $8.5 billion of the total debt, primarily through waivers of interest, service charges, and penalties accumulated over more than two decades of non-payment.

• The 14 countries involved in the Paris Club agreement included Austria, Australia, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Italy, Japan, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the Netherlands, and the United Kingdom.

• Under the 2015 agreement, Cuba would repay the remaining $2.6 billion over 18 years, with annual payments due by October 31 each year; initial payments would start at 1.6% of the total debt and gradually increase to 8.9% by 2033.
• Interest on the debt was forgiven from 2015 to 2020; thereafter, only 1.5% of the total debt would remain due.

• The agreement included a penalty clause: if Cuba failed to make scheduled payments by October 31 of any year, it would incur a 9% interest rate on the overdue amount, along with late interest charges on the arrears.

• The Cuban regime viewed the Paris Club debt agreement positively, seeing it as a means to resolve longstanding issues, enhance business confidence, attract foreign direct investment, and facilitate access to European credit lines.
• During a 2018 diplomatic visit to Cuba, Nguyễn Phú Trọng, General Secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam, wrote off Cuba's official debt to Vietnam, totaling $143.7 million.
• In 2019, Cuba defaulted again on its Paris Club debt; of the approximately $80 million due that year, only a partial payment was made, leaving $30 million unpaid.

• Cuban Deputy Prime Minister Ricardo Cabrisas acknowledged in a letter to Odile Renaud-Basso, president of the Paris Club, that Cuba was unable to fulfill its commitments due to circumstances and expressed the intention to settle arrears by May 31, 2020.

• In May 2020, with payments still outstanding, Deputy PM Cabrisas requested a moratorium on payments for 2019, 2020, and 2021, proposing to resume payments in 2022; as of August 2023, payments had not resumed, and a new payment schedule was under negotiation.
• As of 2011, 96% of Cuba’s electricity was generated from fossil fuels, highlighting heavy reliance on non-renewable energy sources.
• Solar panels were introduced in some rural areas to mitigate issues such as blackouts and brownouts, and to reduce the use of kerosene, promoting cleaner energy alternatives.

• Citizens were encouraged to replace inefficient lamps with newer, energy-efficient models as part of energy conservation efforts; a power tariff was implemented to discourage inefficient electricity use.
• In 2007, Cuba produced an estimated 16.89 billion kilowatt-hours (kWh) of electricity and consumed 13.93 billion kWh, with no electricity exports or imports recorded that year.
• Approximately 25% of Cuba’s electricity is generated on ships using floating power plants, indicating a significant reliance on maritime energy infrastructure.
• As of 2023, eight powerships from Turkey supplied 770 megawatts (MW) of electricity by burning oil, representing a substantial portion of Cuba’s energy production.

• The Energy Revolution, initiated in 2005, is a national program aimed at improving Cuba’s socioeconomic status and transitioning the country into an energy-efficient economy with diverse energy resources.

• Cuba’s energy sector faces limitations due to insufficient resources for optimal power production, compounded by ongoing trade sanctions imposed by the United States, which hinder investment and development.
• Despite receiving multimillion-dollar investments distributed across various power resources, Cuba’s energy sector experiences rolling blackouts to conserve electricity during its economic crisis.

• The outdated electricity grid, damaged by hurricanes in 2004, remains a major obstacle, causing persistent energy crises; efforts to modernize the grid have only restored it to 90% capacity by 2009.

• To address energy shortages, Cuba distributed numerous energy resources including 6,000 small diesel generators, 416 fuel oil generators, 893 diesel generators, 9.4 million incandescent bulbs replaced with energy-saving lamps, 1.33 million fans, 5.5 million electric pressure cookers, 3.4 million electric rice cookers, 200,000 electric water pumps, 2.04 million domestic refrigerators, and 100,000 televisions across territories.
• The country frequently experiences rolling blackouts caused by fuel shortages, leading to shutdowns of many power plants due to lack of fuel supply.
• In October 2024, Cuba suffered a multiday nationwide blackout following the failure of the Antonio Guiteras power plant, with efforts to restart the grid proving unsuccessful.
• Renewable energy has become a major priority for the Cuban government, with a focus on promoting wind and solar power development.
• In March 2017, Cuba enacted a law initiating the widespread deployment of solar panels to every home across the country.

• The primary challenge faced by Cuba’s Energy Revolution program is developing sustainable energy sources while contending with the country’s ongoing development needs, economic sanctions, and the adverse impacts of hurricanes.

• In 2019, Decree-Law 345 was passed, allowing Cuban citizens to purchase photovoltaic solar panels for private use and enabling them to sell any surplus energy back to the state-owned utility, Unión Eléctrica.
• As of 2022, solar power contributed approximately 1.5% to Cuba’s total electricity generation.

• As of August 2012, offshore petroleum exploration in the Gulf of Mexico targeting promising formations had been unproductive, with two reported failures, though additional exploration efforts were planned.
• In both 2007 and 2008, Cuba's estimated oil production was 62,100 barrels per day (bbl/d).
• During the same years, Cuba's oil consumption was approximately 176,000 bbl/d.
• Cuba's oil imports in those years amounted to 104,800 bbl/d.
• Proven oil reserves in Cuba were estimated at 197,300,000 barrels (bbl).
• Venezuela is Cuba's primary source of oil.
• In 2017, Cuba produced and consumed an estimated 1,189 million cubic meters (m³) of natural gas.
• Cuba possesses 70.79 billion cubic meters (bcm) of proved natural gas reserves.
• The nation did not export or import any natural gas in 2017.
• Cuba's agricultural production includes sugarcane, tobacco, citrus fruits, coffee, rice, potatoes, beans, and livestock, reflecting a diverse agrarian economy.
• As of the year 2015, Cuba relied heavily on food imports, with approximately 70–80% of its total food supply being imported from external sources.
• In addition to overall food imports, Cuba imported between 80–84% of the food that was rationed to its population through the state-controlled distribution system.
• Raúl Castro publicly criticized the agricultural sector's inefficiencies by ridiculing the excessive bureaucracy that impeded agricultural productivity and reform efforts.
• In 1996, industrial production in Cuba accounted for nearly 37% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP), amounting to approximately US$6.9 billion.
• In the same year, industrial sectors employed 24% of the Cuban population, which equated to about 2,671,000 individuals.
• A significant increase in sugar prices in 2009 led to a boost in investment and development within Cuba's sugar processing industry.
• By 2003, Cuba's biotechnology and pharmaceutical industry was increasingly important, gaining recognition on the international stage.
• The country exported various products, notably vaccines targeting multiple viral and bacterial pathogens.
• One notable pharmaceutical product is Heberprot-P, developed as a treatment for diabetic foot ulcers, which achieved success in numerous developing countries.
• Cuba has conducted pioneering research in the development of drugs for cancer treatment, establishing itself as a notable player in this field.
• Scientists such as V. Verez-Bencomo received international awards for their contributions to biotechnology and sugar cane research.

• Cuba's biotechnology sector developed primarily as a response to restrictions on technology transfer, international financing, and international trade caused by the United States embargo against Cuba.
• The sector is entirely state-owned, reflecting the Cuban government's centralized control over biotechnological development.
• The development of biotechnology in Cuba was driven by the need to overcome economic and technological limitations imposed by external sanctions and embargoes.
• In the mid-1990s, tourism surpassed sugar as the main source of foreign exchange for Cuba, marking a significant shift in the country's economic structure.
• Havana allocated substantial resources toward developing tourist infrastructure and renovating historic sites to boost the tourism industry.
• Cuban officials estimated that approximately 1.6 million tourists visited Cuba in 1999, generating around $1.9 billion in gross revenue from tourism activities.
• In 2000, the number of foreign visitors to Cuba increased to 1,773,986, with tourism revenue reaching US$1.7 billion.
• By 2012, the number of visitors had grown to approximately 3 million annually, contributing nearly £2 billion in revenue each year.
• The expansion of tourism has led to notable social and economic consequences, including the emergence of a two-tier economy and the development of a "tourist apartheid" system.
• The influx of dollars during the 1990s exacerbated economic disparities, potentially creating a dual economy based on the dollar (used by tourists) and the peso (used by locals).
• Imported goods, including some local products like rum and coffee, became available primarily at dollar-only stores, making them scarce or unavailable at peso prices.
• Cubans earning solely in the peso economy, outside the tourist sector, faced disadvantages due to limited access to dollar-based goods and services.
• Conversely, Cubans with dollar incomes, often derived from the service industry associated with tourism, experienced a higher standard of living, living more comfortably.
• This economic disparity widened the gap in material living standards among Cubans, conflicting with the Cuban government's long-term socialist policies.
• Cuba's retail sector is characterized as small in scale and scope.
• As of September 2012, only a limited number of large shopping centers operated within Havana.
• These shopping centers charged prices comparable to those in the United States, indicating relatively high retail prices.
• The commercial districts that existed prior to the Cuban Revolution were largely shut down following the revolution.
• The majority of retail outlets in Cuba consist of small dollar stores, bodegas (local grocery stores), agro-mercados (farmers' markets), and street stands.
• The financial sector of Cuba remains heavily regulated, indicating strict governmental oversight and control over financial activities.
• Access to credit for entrepreneurial activities in Cuba is significantly hindered, limiting the ability of businesses to obtain necessary funding.

• The impediments to entrepreneurial credit are primarily due to the shallowness of the financial market in Cuba, reflecting a limited depth and breadth of financial institutions and services available.
• In 2023, Canada accounted for the largest share of Cuban exports, representing 30.6% of total exports.
• Of Canada's exports to Cuba, 70 to 80% are processed through Indiana Finance BV, a company owned by the Van 't Wout family, who have close personal ties with Fidel Castro.
• The trend of trade through entities like Indiana Finance BV reflects broader patterns in colonial Caribbean communities with direct political and economic ties to the global economy.
• Cuba's primary import partner is Venezuela, highlighting strong economic relations with the South American nation.
• China is Cuba's second-largest trade partner, holding a 16.9% share of the Cuban export market.
• Cuba began actively seeking foreign investment during the Special Period, a time of economic crisis following the collapse of the Soviet Union in the early 1990s.
• Foreign investors in Cuba are required to form joint ventures with the Cuban government, with the notable exception of Venezuelan investors who can hold 100% ownership due to a bilateral agreement.

• As of early 1998, Cuban officials reported that 332 joint ventures had been established, many of which are loans or management, supplies, or service contracts rather than traditional equity investments.
• These joint ventures often do not resemble Western-style equity investments, reflecting Cuba's unique economic model.

• U.S. legislation, specifically the Helms–Burton Act, imposes sanctions on individuals and entities involved in trafficking in property expropriated from U.S. citizens, constraining foreign investment.
• Cuba's average tariff rate is 10 percent, which influences its trade policies and economic relations.
• As of 2014, Cuba's planned economy, characterized by strict state control, deterred foreign trade and investment due to extensive capital and exchange controls.
• Despite these restrictions, Cuba reported a record foreign investment inflow of 2 billion USD in 2017, indicating a significant increase since 2014.
• It was noted that foreign investment in Cuba had increased dramatically since 2014, reflecting gradual economic opening.
• In September 2019, EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini visited Cuba and stated that the European Union is committed to assisting Cuba in developing its economy.
• The section includes a visual reference to a tobacco plantation in Pinar del Río, emphasizing Cuba’s agricultural exports.
• From 1994 until 2021, Cuba officially maintained two currencies: the national peso (CUP) and the convertible peso (CUC), with the latter often referred to colloquially as "dollar."
• In January 2021, Cuba initiated a currency unification process, providing citizens a six-month period to exchange their remaining CUCs at a fixed rate of one CUC to 24 CUPs.
• The legalization of US dollar possession and use in Cuba occurred in 1994, and by 2004, the US dollar was widely circulated and used across the country.

• To manage the inflow of hard currency from tourism and remittances—estimated at between $500 million and $800 million annually—the Cuban government established state-operated "dollar stores" that sold luxury food, household items, and clothing, which contrasted with necessities available for purchase using the national peso.
• This dual-currency system created a disparity in living standards, favoring those with access to US dollars over those without, leading to economic stratification.

• Jobs that paid dollar salaries or tips from foreign businesses and tourists became highly sought after, with common employment including doctors, engineers, scientists, restaurant workers, and taxi drivers.
• In October 2004, Cuba responded to intensified US economic sanctions and the government's satisfaction with economic recovery by removing US dollars from circulation.
• The government introduced the convertible peso (CUC), which was pegged 1:1 to the US dollar but was not traded internationally.

• A 10% surcharge was applied to cash conversions from US dollars to CUCs, which did not affect conversions from other currencies, thereby incentivizing tourists to bring in foreign currencies such as euros, pounds sterling, or Canadian dollars.
• An increasing number of tourist zones in Cuba began accepting euros as a form of payment.

• Owners of small private restaurants, known as _paladares_, were initially limited to seating no more than 12 people and could only employ family members, with set monthly fees payable regardless of income, and faced stiff fines upon violations of self-employment regulations due to frequent inspections.

• As of 2023, the employment distribution in Cuba was 65% in the public sector and 35% in the private sector, representing a significant shift from the year 2000, when the ratio was 76% public to 23% private, and from 1981, when it was 91% public to 8% private.
• By 2012, over 150,000 farmers had signed agreements to lease land from the government for bonus crops, marking a notable expansion of private agricultural activity.
• Prior to land leasing, homeowners were only permitted to swap property; the transition to allowing buying and selling of land led to increased land prices.

• Urban agriculture in Cuban cities involves small-scale farms on limited parcels, with growing organic gardens (_organopónicos_) becoming popular among city residents who sell their produce locally, thereby avoiding taxes and receiving government support from the Ministry of Agriculture (MINAGRI), including seed houses and advisory services.

• In February 2021, the Cuban government announced plans to permit private sector operation in most economic sectors, leaving only 124 activities under public control, such as national security, health, and educational services.
• In August 2021, Cuba began allowing citizens to establish small and medium-sized private companies, which are permitted to employ up to 100 workers.
• As of 2023, approximately 8,000 private companies had been registered in Cuba.

• In 2021, Cuba's "economic freedom" score from the Heritage Foundation was 28.1, ranking it 176th among the least free economies globally based on criteria such as trade freedom, fiscal freedom, monetary freedom, and business freedom.

• Cuba ranked 31st out of 32 countries in South and Central America in the Heritage Foundation's assessment, with Venezuela identified as a "client state" of Cuba and also ranked among the least free economies; the source of this ranking is noted as needing verification.

• Until June 2019, typical wages in Cuba ranged from 400 non-convertible Cuban pesos (CUP) per month for factory workers to 700 CUP per month for doctors, approximately equivalent to 17–30 US dollars per month.
• Despite low wages, Cuba's Human Development Index (HDI) ranks significantly higher than most Latin American countries, indicating relatively high social development levels.
• After Cuba lost Soviet subsidies in 1991, the country experienced malnutrition and an outbreak of diseases, highlighting economic hardships following the cessation of Soviet support.
• The Cuban government reports one of the lowest poverty levels in the developing world, ranking 6th out of 108 countries globally, 4th in Latin America, and 48th among all nations.
• According to a 2022 report from the Cuban Human Rights Observatory (OCDH), 72 percent of Cubans live below the poverty line.
• Of those living below the poverty line, 21 percent frequently go without breakfast, lunch, or dinner due to insufficient financial resources.
• Pensions in Cuba are among the smallest in the Americas, averaging $9.50 per month.
• In 2009, Raúl Castro increased minimum pensions by 2 dollars, citing the need to compensate those who dedicated much of their lives to work and to uphold socialism.

• Cuba maintains a system of food distribution known as the _Libreta de Abastecimiento_ ("Supplies booklet"), which allocates rations and determines the frequency of supplies for individuals; despite rumors of its abolition, the system persists.
• In June 2019, the Cuban government announced a roughly 300% increase in public sector wages, notably for teachers and health personnel.

• In October 2019, stores were opened where citizens could purchase household supplies and similar goods using electronic cards loaded with foreign currencies (USD, euro, etc.), funded by remittances from emigrants.

• The government acknowledged that the new stores and wage increases were unpopular but deemed necessary to prevent capital flight to countries like Panama, where Cubans travel and resell imported items.

• On 1 January 2021, Cuba launched the "Tarea Ordenamiento" (Ordering Task), a comprehensive reform aimed at eliminating the use of the Cuban convertible peso (CUC) and exclusively using the Cuban peso (CUP) to improve economic efficiency.
• The reform was announced on national television by President Miguel Díaz Canel and Gen. Raúl Castro, then-first secretary of the Cuban Communist Party.
• In February 2021, the government imposed restrictions on 124 private sector activities, particularly in areas such as national security, health, and education.
• Wages and pensions were increased between 4 and 9 times across all sectors; for example, a university instructor's salary rose from 1500 CUP to 5500 CUP.
• The Cuban central bank maintained the official dollar exchange rate at 24 CUP but was unable to sell dollars to the public due to a foreign currency shortage caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.
• Bodegas are local shops that offer basic products such as rice, sugar, salt, beans, cooking oil, matches, and rum at low prices, serving as essential retail outlets for everyday necessities.
• El coppelia is a government-owned facility renowned for providing ice cream, juice, and sweets, functioning as a popular social and recreational venue.
• Paladar refers to small, privately owned restaurant establishments that operate independently of state control, representing a form of private entrepreneurship within Cuba’s hospitality sector.
• La farmacia is a pharmacy that offers low-priced medicines, noted for having the lowest costs for pharmaceuticals anywhere in the world, making healthcare more accessible.
• ETECSA is the national telephone service provider responsible for telecommunications across Cuba, overseeing phone and internet services.
• La feria is a weekly market held on Sundays, owned by the government, functioning as a market-type event where various goods are sold.
• Cervecería Bucanero is a beverage manufacturer that produces both alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks, contributing to Cuba’s beverage industry.
• Ciego Montero is the primary distributor of soft drinks and beverages in Cuba, playing a central role in the distribution network for non-alcoholic beverages.
• Cuba and Venezuela have established agreements whereby Venezuela supplies Cuba with inexpensive oil in exchange for Cuban medical assistance within the Venezuelan healthcare system.
• As of 2015, Cuba ranked third globally in the number of physicians per capita, surpassed only by Monaco and Qatar.
• Cuba dispatches tens of thousands of doctors internationally as a form of aid and to secure favorable trade terms.

• According to Carmelo Mesa-Lago, a Cuban-born US economist, the Venezuelan subsidy to Cuba in nominal terms exceeds the subsidy the Soviet Union previously provided, with Cuba receiving cheap oil valued at approximately $6 billion annually.

• In 2013, Carmelo Mesa-Lago stated that if Venezuelan assistance ceases, Cuba's industry and transportation sectors would become paralyzed, affecting electricity, sugar mills, and other vital industries.

• From an economic perspective, Cuba is far more dependent on Venezuela than vice versa; as of 2012, Venezuela contributed 20.8% to Cuba’s GDP, whereas Cuba accounted for only about 4% of Venezuela’s GDP.

• Due to this dependency, Cuba's economic stability is heavily impacted by Venezuela’s crises; during Venezuela’s 2016 economic crisis, characterized by inflation approaching 800% and a 19% contraction in GDP, Cuba did not receive the full amount of subsidized oil and payments.
• Further budget cuts to Cuba’s subsidies and oil supplies are planned for 2018, marking the third consecutive year of such reductions, though this information requires an update.
• As of 2009, Cuba's total revenues amounted to $47.08 billion, while expenditures reached $50.34 billion.
• The country's public debt constituted 34.6% of its Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• Cuba maintained an account balance of $513 million.
• The nation held reserves of foreign exchange and gold totaling $4.647 billion.
• Government spending accounted for approximately 67% of Cuba's GDP.
• Public debt represented around 35% of the domestic economy.
• Despite implementing reforms, the Cuban government continues to exert significant influence over the economy.
• The highest individual income tax rate in Cuba is 50%.
• The top corporate tax rate is 30%, with a higher rate of 35% applied to wholly foreign-owned companies.
• Additional taxes include a tax on property transfers and a sales tax.
• The overall tax burden in Cuba is 24.42% of GDP.
• During the 19th century, Cuba's income distribution compared favorably with that of other Latin American countries.
• According to Susan Eckstein, available data from that period should be viewed cautiously, as they likely only provide a rough approximation of the actual conditions at the time.
• Significant social inequalities existed between urban and rural areas, with disparities in wealth and living standards.
• Racial inequalities were also prominent, notably between white populations and Black populations.
• Cuba faced economic challenges including trade issues and high unemployment rates.
• In 2021, Cuba was ranked 83rd out of 191 countries on the Human Development Index, placing it within the high human development category.
